medium: Earth from Sayreville, NJ, on muslin-mounted paper
creditline: Museum purchase, Mary Trumbull Adams Art Fund

makers.displaydate: Born 1933, Los Angeles, CA; active New York, NY and Carpenteria, CA
makers.displaymaker: Michelle Stuart, Born 1933, Los Angeles, CA; active New York, NY and Carpenteria, CA

texts.textentryhtml: [Leslie Tonkonow Artworks and Projects, New York, New York], purchased by the Princeton University Art Museum, 2012.
texts.remarks: as per invoice in curatorial file. AP.

texts.textentryhtml: An avid student of geology, cartography, and archaeology, Stuart has long explored the myriad investments that humans make in the natural world. In 1976, at the suggestion of artist Charles Simonds, she began to frequent the failing sand and clay quarries in Sayreville. Reminiscent of a Plains Indian parfleche, or rawhide bag, Sayreville Quarry History Book consists of earth that Stuart harvested on-site and muslin-mounted paper she made by hand. Using a technique known as frottage, she rubbed soil and pebbles into the support, capturing the distinctive texture, color, and aroma of Sayreville sediment.

bibliography.boilertext: Kelly Baum, et. al., New Jersey as non-site, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 2013).
bibliography.citation: Kelly Baum, et. al., New Jersey as non-site, (Princeton, NJ: Princeton University Art Museum, 2013)., p. 29 (illus.)
